title: Type 2 Diabetes and Depression: Are They Linked?

content: As someone diagnosed with bipolar II depression and type 2 diabetes, I viewed myself as an unlucky outlier who had managed to score not one, but two chronic conditions.
Over the years, busy managing both, I rarely considered how or if the two might be linked.
But the more I learned about type 2 diabetes, the more aware I became that diabetes and depression frequently travel together.

People with type 2, for example, are about twice as likely to experience depression when compared to those without diabetes. People with a history of depression also have a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
What caused this was considerably less clear to me.
I understood, for example, that people with type 2 were sometimes overweight or obese and that overeating can be a sign of depression. But I also knew that not everyone who overeats is depressed.

I also knew from personal experience that the stress of dealing daily with diabetes management could lead to depression. But so-called diabetes burnout doesn’t always lead to a serious mental health diagnosis.

content: Then there were the riddles of biology. What connected the inability of my body to use insulin with the loss of pleasure and engagement that defined my depression? And if my type 2 diabetes and history of depression were linked, had one caused the other?
And if so, in the spirit of the chicken or the egg, which came first -- type 2 diabetes or depression?
Or were the two conditions caused by completely unrelated factors?

While no one has yet solved the chicken or the egg questions around diabetes and depression, a new study helped to answer some of these questions by showing that depression can play a direct role in the development of type 2 diabetes.

As a result, some doctors are recommending that a history of depression should be added to the list of risk factors for developing type 2 diabetes , so that people can be supported to avoid developing the condition.

Researchers also answered some of the biological questions by locating seven shared genetic variants between the two conditions. The variants impact insulin production and inflammation in the brain, pancreas, and fat cells. Changes these genes can make inside the body might explain how depression increases the risk of type 2 diabetes.

content: So what’s the takeaway here? I think there are a few:
As always, if you’re facing one or both conditions, consider speaking with your doctor or therapist, not only to catch a possible diabetes diagnosis but to review how you can better manage your care.
None of this is easy, but based on my personal experience, it is doable. Taking action can lead to better physical and mental health.
Learn, share, and connect with others on WebMD’s Type 2 Diabetes Facebook Support Group.
Photo Credit: Ascent Xmedia / Stone via Getty Images
bullets: If you have a history of depression, you might consider getting checked for early signs of type 2.
While there isn’t a cause and effect of type 2 on depression, similar risk factors shared between two conditions -- obesity, and the lack of physical exercise -- might impact them both.

The demands of day-to-day dealing with type 2 diabetes can be a factor in developing depression, so keep tabs on your moods and speak with someone if your diabetes care makes you begin to feel overwhelmed.
